src/environments/virtualenv.js
src/environments.js
content:
import Environment from './environments/environment'
import CondaEnv from './environments/condaenv'
import VirtualEnv from './environments/virtualenv'

export {
  Environment,
  CondaEnv,
  VirtualEnv
}

name: src/executables/conda.js
src/executables/executable.js
Executable
description:
A specific file on a computer that
can be run

params.name: path
params.description: the full path to the binary

params.name: command
params.description: a command that executes this file

params.name: isDefault
params.description: whether the command is first in the PATH

name: paths
description: Any paths that you can find this executable at (symlinked or otherwise)

name: defaultCommands
description:
The commands for which this executable is first in line to run
e.g., running which returns it

name: isDefault
description: Is this executable the default for any commands?
todo:
I think this only exists because of legacy,
should probably get rid of it and replace with examining
defaultCommands instead

name: addError
description:
Take any rescued error and attach it to the object, e.g.
pass errors from the command line to the end user

params.name: error
params.description: an error object, typically rescued from elsewhere

name: addCommand
description:
Add a command that this executable is first in line for, 
e.g. if you run blahblah from the shell this executes

name: mergeField
description:
When merging an ExecutableCollection, this is what you group
the executables by. Mostly exists because PipExecutable on
Windows has different paths but point to the same package
install directory, which makes them equivalent.

return.description: the value that makes the executable unique

name: requestVersion
description:
Gets the version of the executable by shelling out and 
running --version

name: setRawVersion
description:
Given a version-y string, do slight cleanup and set the
executable's rawVersion. Typically comes from stdout/stderr.

params.name: version
params.description: the version string, fresh from terminal output

name: rawVersion
description: The raw output from stdout/stderr of --version

name: cleanVersion
description: Clean up the rawVersion, pulling out the actual version number

name: version
description:
The version number of the program, typically cleaned up in
a subclass

name: setVersion
description: Query for and set the rawVersion and version

name: setStats
description:
Query for the executable file's creation/modification/access time
and save it to the object

name: path
description:
When you're looking for a path, but don't necessarily care
if it's the symlinked one or the non-symlinked on?
todo: it says 'FIXME' but I think it should just be 'get rid of me'

return.description: the best known path for the executable

name: realpath
description: The path of the executable, or the target of a symlinked executable

name: realpath
description: Set the realpath

name: populate
description: Fills in all of the details of the executable

name: setExtras
description:
Subclasses that need extra details (lists of packages, etc) 
override this method

name: addPath
description: Adds a known path to this executable (e.g. a symlink)

name: toJSON
description:
Converts the executable's data to a JSON-friendly object
it's mostly so we can rename _realpath to realpath

name: findOne
description:
Given a command name, creates an Executable from the executable
file that would have been run had you typed the command in (e.g. which)
todo: what if one is not found?

name: findAll
description:
Given a command name or list of commands, returns an ExecutableCollection
of all the executables with that name your computer might know about
Looks in the path as well as looking in common paths.
The Executables are all merged together, so you don't have different
symlinks pointing at the same file.
Each actual binary file yields one Executable

params.name: command
params.description: the command or a list of commands

name: findAllWithoutMerge
description:
Given a command name or list of commands, returns an ExecutableCollection
of all the executables with that name your computer might know about
Looks in the path as well as looking in common paths.
The Executables are not merged
Each path yields one Executable

name: findByWhich
description: Uses which to find all of the paths for a given command

name: findByPaths
description: Manually searches paths to find executables with a given name

name: searchPaths
description: Paths to manually search in for executables

name: src/executables/executable_collection.js
src/executables/jupyter.js
src/executables/pip.js
src/executables/python.js
src/executables/virtualenv.js
src/executables.js
content:
import Executable from './executables/executable'
import PipExecutable from './executables/pip'
import PythonExecutable from './executables/python'
import JupyterExecutable from './executables/jupyter'
import CondaExecutable from './executables/conda'
import VirtualEnvExecutable from './executables/virtualenv'

export {
  Executable,
  PipExecutable,
  PythonExecutable,
  JupyterExecutable,
  CondaExecutable,
  VirtualEnvExecutable
}

name: src/executive.js
src/functions.js
src/index.js
